what: /charts/draw: Draw child data on growth chart
text: R bash Maria preterm born 27 weeks gestational age. already uploaded data. may now plot growth data A4 chart preterms follows:  Maria’s growth plotted preterm chart, 0-15 months Alternatively, may upload data new child Laura plot data one step: A4 sized charts, recommend generate plot query arguments list(height = 29.7/2.54, width = 21/2.54), illustrated . want change chart’s size HTML, use .width knitr chunk option, e.g. set .width="500px". gives following output.  Laura’s growth plotted chart Dutch girls, 0-4 years JAMES features built-prediction module based curve matching. Suppose want predict Laura’s height 3y9m Laura 2 years old. following chart plots 25 matches Laura grey curves. variation grey curves age 3y9m indicates likely variation prediction. blue line indicates Laura’s predicted height age 3y9m. square charts, use query arguments list(height = 18/2.54, width = 18/2.54) generate plot. order get age units previous chart, calculate .width 500/21*18 = "429px".  Predict Laura’s future height age 3y9m. Upload maria.json draw height data default chart produce SVG file. Specify proper width height query parameters. need set chartcode selector parameters choose different chart. alternative read data URL, use application/json protocol specify parameters.
code: r5 <- james_post(host = host,                   path = "/charts/draw/svglite",                   session = r1$session,                  chartcode = "PMAAN27", selector = "chartcode",                  query = list(height = 29.7/2.54, width = 21/2.54)) writeLines(r5$parsed, con = filename_chart1) fn <- system.file("extdata/bds_v3.0/smocc/Laura_S.json", package = "jamesdemodata") r6 <- james_post(host = host,                  path = "/charts/draw/svglite", txt = fn,                   chartcode = "NMBA", selector = "chartcode",                  query = list(height = 29.7/2.54, width = 21/2.54)) writeLines(r6$parsed, con = filename_chart2) r7 <- james_post(host = host,                   path = "/charts/draw/svglite", txt = fn,                   chartcode = "NMBH", dnr = "2-4",                  lo = 2.0, hi = 3.75, nmatch = 25,                  show_future = TRUE, show_realized = TRUE,                  query = list(height = 18/2.54, width = 18/2.54)) writeLines(r7$parsed, con = filename_chart3) source auth_curl.sh auth_curl -sX 'POST' $(cat .host)'/charts/draw/svglite?width=7.09&height=7.09' \ -H 'accept: image/*' \ -F 'txt=@maria.json;type=application/json' > maria1.svg source auth_curl.sh auth_curl -sX 'POST' $(cat .host)'/charts/draw/svglite?width=8.27&height=11.69' \ -H 'accept: image/*' \ -F "chartcode='PMAAN27'" \ -F "selector='chartcode'" \ -F 'txt=@maria.json;type=application/json' > maria2.svg source auth_curl.sh  BASE_URL=$(cat .host | sed 's|/modules/james$||') auth_curl -sX 'POST' \ $(cat .host)'/charts/draw/svglite?width=8.27&height=11.69' \ -H 'accept: image/*' \ -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \ -d '{ "txt": "'$BASE_URL'/ocpu/library/jamesdemodata/extdata/bds_v3.0/smocc/Laura_S.json", "chartcode" : "NMBA", "selector" : "chartcode"}' > laura.svg

text: R bash JAMES contains wide variety built-growth charts. chart unique chartcode. typical chart code looks like NJAA. obtain full list chart codes charts object data frame 478 rows (charts) following variables: JAMES contains charts various child populations. charts syndrome (DS), Hindustan (HS), Moroccan (MA), Dutch (NL)), preterm (PT) Turkish (TU) children living Netherlands Growth Standards (WHOblue, WHOpink). charts contain references height (hgt), weight (wgt), head circumference (hdc), weight--height (wfh), body mass index (bmi) D-score (dsc), well combined charts multiple references A4 format (front, back, -hdc). important index variables population side: URL {host}/site (see ) displays currently active chart code field left sidebar. Restrict listing references:
code: r <- james_post(host = host, path = "charts/list/json") charts <- r$parsed names(charts) [1] "chartgrp"   "chartcode"  "population" "sex"        "design"     [6] "side"       "language"   "week" with(charts, table(population, side)) side population -hdc back bmi dsc front hdc hgt wfh wgt    DS         0    6   2   0     6   6   6   4   2    HS         4    2   2   0     6   2   6   4   2    MA         0    6   2   0     6   6   6   4   2    NL         2    8   2   4     8   8   8   4   4    PT         0   24   0  48    48  24  48   0  48    TU         0    6   2   0     6   6   6   4   2    WHOblue    0    0   0  26     2   1   2   1   1    WHOpink    0    0   0  26     2   1   2   1   1 source auth_curl.sh auth_curl -sX 'POST' \ $(cat .host)'/charts/list/json' \ -H 'accept: application/json' \ -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \ -d '{ "chartgrp": "who" }'

text: R bash JAMES implements several screening algorithms. /screeners/list end point provides detailed information . currently different codes. Codes ending 31, e.g., 1031 2031 indicate normal growth, whereas code ending 41, 42 , signal - according guidelines - child referred investigation. get details guidelines head circumference
code: r <- james_post(   host = host,   path = "/screeners/list/json",   session = r1$session ) names(r$parsed) with(r$parsed, table(yname, Categorie)) source auth_curl.sh auth_curl -sX 'POST' \ $(cat .host)'/screeners/list/json' \ -H 'accept: application/json' \ -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \ -d '{"ynames": "hdc"}'

what: /screeners/apply: Apply growth screeners to child data
text: R bash /screeners/apply end point applies standard screeners child data. Invoke screeners procedure calculates, per outcome, intervals recent measurement earlier measurements; tests whether intervals produces signal according screening algorithm; reports recent non-standard signal indicate abnormal growth. example, returned codes (1031, 2031, 3031) end “31”, signals normal growth. full table return codes messages can obtained /screeners/list end point (see ). several possibilities visualise integrate multiple evaluations per curve performed step 2 one advice. May 2023, JAMES returned advice combination time point outcome, table presented lot output difficult act one. Since May 2023, JAMES reports one signal per curve.

text: R bash /site end point provides interactive site containing charts, without child data. end point primarily useful obtain quick overview available charts.
code: browseURL(file.path(host, "site"))

text: R bash /site/request end point creates URL personalised, interactive site containing charts. Run command paste generated URL address field browser. starting chart chosen JAMES depends age child. systems, command may fail browser error [400] connect server [localhost]. alternative break request two steps. First, create session uploading child data, use session create URL personalised site. start uploading data JAMES het r$session. , can use either site\request manual construction URL site: Paste generated URL address field browser. initial page shown depends child’s age. two-step approach also works remote servers. practice, use two-step approach stabler reliable.
code: r <- james_post(   host = host,   path = "/site/request/json",   sitehost = host,   txt = js ) r$parsed [1] "https://james.groeidiagrammen.nl/site?session=x0bce05b69f1b3f" fn <- system.file("examples/maria.json", package = "bdsreader") r <- james_post(host = host, path = "data/upload/json", txt = fn)  # URL construction by /site/request site1 <- james_post(   host = host,   path = "site/request/json",   sitehost = host,   session = r$session,   upload = FALSE ) site1 JAMES request:   Path    : site/request/json   Status  : 201   Session : x0a61571200eb53  Parsed response: [1] "https://james.groeidiagrammen.nl/site?session=x074bbb1a8eaf59" # Or manual URL construction parsed_host <- httr::parse_url(host) combined_path <- paste(parsed_host$path, "site", sep = "/") combined_path <- gsub("//+", "/", combined_path) site2 <- httr::modify_url(   url = host,   path = combined_path,   query = list(session = r$session) ) site2 [1] "https://james.groeidiagrammen.nl/site?session=x074bbb1a8eaf59" source auth_curl.sh auth_curl -sX 'POST' \ $(cat .host)'/site/request/json' \ -H 'accept: application/json' \ -H 'Content-Type: multipart/form-data' \ -F "sitehost='$(cat .host)'" \ -F 'txt=@maria.json;type=application/json' ["https://james.groeidiagrammen.nl/site?session=x034ad79b7bdaf3"]

what: /blend/request: Obtain a blend from multiple end points
text: R bash /blend/request end point returns results multiple end points, thus functions one-stop shop. However, currently support graphics output, use /{session}/{info}/svglite /charts/draw/svglite charts. two-step approach : Note: example requires OpenCPU library access may work ACC server.

text: JAMES supports open authenticated access depending deployment environment: Test server (https://james.groeidiagrammen.nl): Open access, authentication required ACC PROD server : Requires Bearer token authentication document uses authentication throughout compatibility ACC server. authentication mechanism handled behind scenes uses simple convention makes easy switch different deployment environments. authentication system document uses several files environment variables: Note: .bearer .host files temporary created rendering document. Add apikey-acc.txt, .bearer, .host .gitignore prevent accidentally committing sensitive information. use ACC server (authenticated JAMES instance), follow steps: Contact JAMES administrator obtain API key ACC environment. Save key file named apikey-acc.txt (apikey-prod.txt) vignettes/articles/ directory: Run authentication script obtain Bearer token: script: 1. Reads API key apikey-acc.txt 2. Sends ACC authentication endpoint 3. Saves returned Bearer token .bearer 4. Returns exit code 0 success, 1 failure Bearer token typically valid limited time (e.g., 24 hours). Re-run script token expires. R code: setup chunk automatically loads Bearer token JAMES_BEARER_TOKEN environment variable, used jamesclient functions: bash code: Use auth_curl helper function instead curl: auth_curl function automatically adds Authorization: Bearer {token} header .bearer file exists. prefer handle authentication manually without helper scripts: R: bash: switch different JAMES servers (test, acc, dev), change target_host variable {r host} setup chunk beginning document: document automatically: Set appropriate server URL host variable Create .host file bash chunks Load authentication tokens available Use authenticated requests needed 401 Unauthorized errors: Token may expired - re-run ./authenticate-acc.sh Check .bearer file exists empty Verify JAMES_BEARER_TOKEN set: Sys.getenv("JAMES_BEARER_TOKEN") jamesclient::james_post() jamesclient::james_get() functions rely JAMES_BEARER_TOKEN authentication Token found: Ensure apikey-acc.txt exists contains API key Check ’re running commands vignettes/articles/ directory Verify authenticate-acc.sh execute permissions: chmod +x authenticate-acc.sh Connection timeout: Check network connection Verify ACC server URL correct Check ’re behind proxy requires configuration
code: echo "your-api-key-here" > vignettes/articles/apikey-acc.txt cd vignettes/articles ./authenticate-acc.sh # Token is automatically loaded from .bearer file # jamesclient functions automatically use JAMES_BEARER_TOKEN r <- james_post(host = host, path = "version/json") source auth_curl.sh  # Instead of: curl -X POST https://server/endpoint # Use: auth_curl -sX POST $(cat .host)/endpoint # Read the bearer token bearer_token <- trimws(readLines(".bearer", n = 1))  # Add to requests library(httr2) resp <- request(paste0(host, "/version/json")) |>   req_headers(Authorization = paste("Bearer", bearer_token)) |>   req_perform() # Read the bearer token TOKEN=$(cat .bearer)  # Add to curl requests curl -sX POST https://server/endpoint \   -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" target_host <- "dev"   # localhost for development target_host <- "test"  # No authentication needed target_host <- "acc"   # Requires authentication target_host <- "prod"  # Requires authentication

text: Run authentication script obtain Bearer token: script: 1. Reads API key apikey-acc.txt 2. Sends ACC authentication endpoint 3. Saves returned Bearer token .bearer 4. Returns exit code 0 success, 1 failure Bearer token typically valid limited time (e.g., 24 hours). Re-run script token expires.
code: cd vignettes/articles ./authenticate-acc.sh

text: R code: setup chunk automatically loads Bearer token JAMES_BEARER_TOKEN environment variable, used jamesclient functions: bash code: Use auth_curl helper function instead curl: auth_curl function automatically adds Authorization: Bearer {token} header .bearer file exists.
code: # Token is automatically loaded from .bearer file # jamesclient functions automatically use JAMES_BEARER_TOKEN r <- james_post(host = host, path = "version/json") source auth_curl.sh  # Instead of: curl -X POST https://server/endpoint # Use: auth_curl -sX POST $(cat .host)/endpoint

text: prefer handle authentication manually without helper scripts: R: bash:
code: # Read the bearer token bearer_token <- trimws(readLines(".bearer", n = 1))  # Add to requests library(httr2) resp <- request(paste0(host, "/version/json")) |>   req_headers(Authorization = paste("Bearer", bearer_token)) |>   req_perform() # Read the bearer token TOKEN=$(cat .bearer)  # Add to curl requests curl -sX POST https://server/endpoint \   -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN"

text: switch different JAMES servers (test, acc, dev), change target_host variable {r host} setup chunk beginning document: document automatically: Set appropriate server URL host variable Create .host file bash chunks Load authentication tokens available Use authenticated requests needed
code: target_host <- "dev"   # localhost for development target_host <- "test"  # No authentication needed target_host <- "acc"   # Requires authentication target_host <- "prod"  # Requires authentication

title: Joint Automatic Measurement and Evaluation System
text: JAMES web service creating interpreting charts child growth development. current version provides access high-quality growth charts used Dutch youth health care; interchanges data coded according Basisdataset JGZ; screens abnormal height, weight head circumference; converts developmental data D-score; predicts future growth development. JAMES RESTful API runs remote host. following sections illustrate client can make requests JAMES using various client languages. principle, HTTP client work JAMES. document highlights applications service provides pointers relevant background information. service aids monitoring evaluating childhood growth. JAMES created maintained Netherlands Organisation Applied Scientific Research TNO. Please contact Stef van Buuren <stef.vanbuuren tno.nl> information.

text: txt JSON string, URL, file BDS data JSON format. Data conform BDS JGZ 3.2.5 specification. session OpenCPU session key uploaded data format JSON schema version, e.g., "3.0". Used uploading. chartcode Optional. code requested growth chart. selector Either "chartcode", "data" "derive". function can calculate chart code looking child data (method "data") user input (method "derive"). detail, following behaviour decides growth charts: "data" Calculate chart code individual data. setting chooses "optimal" chart given individual set data. "derive" Calculate chart code combination user data: chartgrp, agegrp, side, sex, etn, ga. method use individual data. Use setting chart choice needs reactive user input. "chartcode" Take string specified chartcode valid tgt object, function simply obeys selector setting. valid tgt object found, "chartcode" argument taken. However, "chartcode" empty, function selects method "derive". loc Deprecated. Use session instead. ind_loc Legacy. disappear Nov 2022. Use loc instead. ... Ignored

title: Derive advice on chart choice from data — convert_tgt_chartadvice
text: list following elements population string identifying population, e.g. 'NL','MA', 'TU' 'PT'. sex string "male", "female" "undifferentiated". design letter indicating chart design: '' = 0-15m, 'B' = 0-4y, 'C' = 1-21y, 'D' = 0-21y, 'E' = 0-4ya. side string indicating side yname: 'front', 'back', '', 'hgt', 'wgt', 'hdc', 'bmi', 'wfh' language language chart drawn. Currently "dutch" charts implemented, population == "PT" may also "english". week scalar indicating gestational age birth. used population == "PT". chartcode string indicating chart code. chartgrp string indicating chart group, either "nl2010", "preterm", "", "gsed1", "gsed1pt". agegrp string indicating age group, either "0-15m", "0-4y", "1-21y" "0-21y". dnr string indicating donor dataset matching, either "smocc", "lollypop", "terneuzen" "pops". slider_list string indicating set slider labels, either "0_2", "0_4" "0_29". period character vector two elements, indicating first last period matching analysis, e.g. like c("3m", "14m").

title: Draw growth chart — draw_chart
text: txt JSON string, URL, file BDS data JSON format. Data conform BDS JGZ 3.2.5 specification. session OpenCPU session key uploaded data format JSON schema version, e.g., "3.0". Used uploading. chartcode Optional. code requested growth chart. selector Either "chartcode", "data" "derive". function can calculate chart code looking child data (method "data") user input (method "derive"). detail, following behaviour decides growth charts: "data" Calculate chart code individual data. setting chooses "optimal" chart given individual set data. "derive" Calculate chart code combination user data: chartgrp, agegrp, side, sex, etn, ga. method use individual data. Use setting chart choice needs reactive user input. "chartcode" Take string specified chartcode valid tgt object, function simply obeys selector setting. valid tgt object found, "chartcode" argument taken. However, "chartcode" empty, function selects method "derive". chartgrp chart group: 'nl2010', 'preterm', '', 'gsed1', 'gsed1pt' character(0) agegrp Either '0-15m', '0-4y', '1-21y', '0-21y' '0-4ya'. Age group '0-4ya' provides 0-4 chart weight age (design E). sex Either 'male' 'female' etn Either 'netherlands', 'turkish', 'moroccan' 'hindustani' ga Gestational age (completed weeks) side Either 'front', 'back', '-hdc' '' curve_interpolation logical indicating whether curve interpolation shoud applied. quiet Logical indicating whether chart code written standard output. Default quiet = TRUE. dnr Donor data, Prediction horizon: "0-2", "2-4" "4-18". May also "smocc", "lollypop", "terneuzen" "pops". specified, choice made internally. lo Value left visit coded string, e.g. "4w" "7.5m" hi Value right visit coded string, e.g. "4w" "7.5m" nmatch Integer. Number matches needed. nmatch == 0L matches sought. exact_sex logical indicating whether sex matched exactly exact_ga logical indicating whether gestational age matched exactly break_ties logical indicating whether ties broken randomly. default (TRUE) breaks ties randomly. show_realized logical indicating whether realized growth target child drawn show_future logical indicating whether predicted growth target child drawn draw_grob Logical. chart plotted current device? Default TRUE. internal use . loc Deprecated. Use session instead. bds_data Legacy. disappear Nov 2022. Use txt instead. ind_loc Legacy. disappear Nov 2022. Use loc instead. ... Ignored

what: Load data from a previous OpenCPU session on same host — get_session_object
title: Load data from a previous OpenCPU session on same host — get_session_object
text: function loads data previous OpenCPU session host. assumption sessions stored path /tmp/ocpu-store. Provides short-cut data eliminating need make self-requests.

title: List available growth charts — list_charts
text: chartgrp Optional. String chart group name, e.g. chartgrp = "". omitted, list_charts() return charts groups. ... used

title: List available growth charts — list_charts
text: data.frame eight columns: chartgrp Chart group code chartcode Unique chart code population Population code: DS (Syndrome), HS (Hindostanic), MA (Morrocan), NL (Dutch), PT (Preterm), TU (Turkish), WHOblue (male), WHOpink (female) sex Either "male"  "female" design Chart design : 0-15m, B: 0-4y (WFH), C: 1-21y, D: 0-21y, E: 0-4y (WFA) side Outcome measure: hgt (height), wgt (weight), hdc (head circumference), wfh (weight height), bmi (body mass index), front (multiple), back (multiple), -hdc (back, head circumference) language Chart language: dutch week Weeks gestation 25-36, missing (>= 37 weeks)

text: txt JSON string, URL, file BDS data JSON format. Data conform BDS JGZ 3.2.5 specification. p Reference percentile indicating expected probability positive van Wiechen outcome given child age. Higher values correspond easier items. n Number van Wiechen items suggest. default returns items within set probability limits. vwc Vector string values matching van Wiechen milestones. Bypasses calculations directly supply milestones interest session Optional session key data already uploaded sitehost. format JSON schema version, e.g., "3.0". Used uploading. loc Deprecated. Use session instead. ... Ignored

what: Provides multiple outputs in one request — request_blend
title: Provides multiple outputs in one request — request_blend
text: Function request_blend() acts one-stop-shop obtain multiple outputs one request.

title: Provides multiple outputs in one request — request_blend
code: request_blend(   txt = "",   sitehost = "",   session = "",   blend = "standard",   loc = "",   ... )

title: Provides multiple outputs in one request — request_blend
text: txt JSON string, URL, file BDS data JSON format. Data conform BDS JGZ 3.2.5 specification. sitehost server renders site. Defaults "http://localhost:8080" specified. session Optional session key data already uploaded sitehost. blend string indicating requested blend. default ("standard") returns results standard end points produces tables. Graphs currently supported. loc Deprecated. Use session instead. ... Ignored

title: Provides multiple outputs in one request — request_blend
text: default blend = "standard" return list following components: txt String, file URL child data session Session uploaded child data child Processed child level data time Processed time level data screeners Results application screeners child data site URL personalised child data

title: Provides multiple outputs in one request — request_blend
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ fn <- system.file("extdata", "bds_v2.0", "smocc", "Laura_S.json", package = "jamesdemodata") results <- request_blend(txt = fn) } # }

what: Request site containing personalised charts — request_site
title: Request site containing personalised charts — request_site
text: Constructs URL JAMES site showing personalised growth chart. Optionally uploads data server returns session-based URL.

title: Request site containing personalised charts — request_site
code: request_site(   txt = "",   sitehost = "",   session = "",   format = "3.0",   upload = TRUE,   loc = "",   ... )

title: Request site containing personalised charts — request_site
text: txt JSON string, URL, file BDS data JSON format. Data conform BDS JGZ 3.2.5 specification. sitehost server renders site. Defaults "http://localhost:8080" specified. session Optional session key data already uploaded sitehost. format JSON schema version, e.g., "3.0". Used uploading. upload Logical. TRUE, uploads txt returns URL ?session=. FALSE, appends ?txt= directly (recommended). loc Deprecated. Use session instead. ... Ignored

title: Request site containing personalised charts — request_site
text: character string URL pointing personalised JAMES site.

title: Request site containing personalised charts — request_site
code: fn <- system.file("testdata", "client3.json", package = "james") js <- jsonlite::toJSON(jsonlite::fromJSON(fn), auto_unbox = TRUE) url <- "https://groeidiagrammen.nl/ocpu/library/james/testdata/client3.json" host <- "http://localhost:8080" host <- "https://james.groeidiagrammen.nl"  # solutions that upload the data and create a URL with the `?session=` query parameter if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # upload file - works with docker on localhost site <- request_site(sitehost = host, txt = fn) # browseURL(site)  # upload JSON string site <- request_site(sitehost = host, txt = js) site # browseURL(site)  # upload URL site <- request_site(sitehost = host, txt = url) site # browseURL(site)  # same, but in two steps, starting from file name # this also works for js and url resp <- jamesclient::james_post(path = "data/upload", txt = fn) session <- resp$session site <- request_site(sitehost = host, session = session) site # browseURL(site)  # solutions that create an immediate ?txt=[..data..] query # this method does not create a cache on the server site <- request_site(sitehost = host, txt = js, upload = FALSE) # browseURL(site) } # }

title: Selects the growth chart — select_chart

title: Selects the growth chart — select_chart
text: target list elements psn (persondata) xyz (timedata). chartgrp chart group: 'nl2010', 'preterm', '', 'gsed1', 'gsed1pt' character(0) agegrp Either '0-15m', '0-4y', '1-21y', '0-21y' '0-4ya'. Age group '0-4ya' provides 0-4 chart weight age (design E). sex Either 'male' 'female' etn Either 'netherlands', 'turkish', 'moroccan' 'hindustani' ga Gestational age (completed weeks) side Either 'front', 'back', '-hdc' '' language Language: 'dutch' 'english' (used)

title: Uploads, parses, converts and stores data on the server — upload_data
text: txt JSON string, URL file auto_format Logical. format read data? Default TRUE. format String. JSON data schema version number. currently three schemas supported: "1.0", "1.1", "2.0", "3.0" "3.1". Formats "1.0" "1.1" included backward compatibility . Use format = "3.1" new applications. schema file name (optionally including path) JSON validation schema. schema argument overrides format. function extracts version number basename, overwrites format argument version number. validate Logical. JSON-input validated JSON-schema? default (FALSE) bypasses checking. Set validate = TRUE obtain diagnostic information jsonvalidate::json_validate() function. append_ddi DDI responses appended? (used JSON schema V1.0 V2.0) intermediate Logical. TRUE function writes JSON files intermediate result working directory. 1. input.json: JSON input data; 2. bds.json: data frame info per BDS; 3. ddi.json: result recoding BDS GSED item names; 4. psn.json: known fixed child covariates; 5. xy.json: time-varying variables. verbose Show verbose output centile::y2z() ... Used additional parameters

title: james 1.7.3 (August 2025)
text: Adds template inst/spec/openapi..yaml function james:::update_openapi_spec(), updates OpenAPI template current JAMES version saves inst/spec/openapi.yaml. enables: Easy maintenance OpenAPI specification. Serving API documentation directly JAMES server https://<host>/docs, removing dependency SwaggerHub. Includes versioned JSON schemas (bds_vx.y.json) data exchange, now bundled package downloadable https://<host>/schemas. Updates R JavaScript code default localhost:8080 OpenCPU server URL (previously localhost:80). Port 8080 used prevent confusion Docker system-level port 80. Adds qmd/JAMES_version_maintaince.qmd, Quarto file run version change. script updates version numbers across package, including OpenAPI spec, index.html, getting_started.Rmd vignette.

title: james 1.7.3 (August 2025)
text: Updates package use R 4.5.0. Cleans renv.lock removing development-packages (e.g., "roxygen2", "devtools", "desc", "evaluate", "jamesdemodata", "pkgload") dependencies. reduces package’s footprint production environments. running renv::restore() install production dependencies, call james:::install_dev_packages() install development tools. include development packages renv.lock. snapshot production dependencies defined DESCRIPTION file using renv::snapshot(). Adds test test-request_site() demonstrates: request_site() fails nested data uploads using localhost. working alternative solution. change ensures jamesdemo Shiny app can now also demonstrate fully functioning localhost server. Adapts links reflect change BDS-maintenance NCJ NICTIZ Updates getting_started.Rmd work localhost:8080 show two-step data upload

title: james 0.23.0
text: Major update incorporating following breaking changes since james 0.16.0 JAMES now consistently uses txt parameter JSON child data input, R package javascript. replaces arguments like bds_data bds. JAMES now consistently uses loc parameters URL uploaded child data. replaces arguments named location, ind_loc ind. query parameter ?ind= URL’s outdated, superseeded ?loc=. analysis functions now accept txt loc input. specified, txt takes precedence. consistency, function upload_txt replaces update_bds. Function screen_curves longer returns list, screening results, consistent naming. new function custom_list takes task screen_curves. Removed functions: draw_chart_bds, draw_chart_ind, draw_plot (replaced draw_chart). Enhancements: site accept now ?txt= query parameter, bypasses need upload data. new function request_site constructs URL’s personalised sites. new function custom_list creates custom list return values (formerly implemented screen_curves), adds new element containing D-score last observation. new function update_txt() upload data JAMES JAMES server location now independent data location, uploaded data can stored external URL control client. javascript reduces number calls via OpenCPU, resulting speedier site updates. Function draw_chart gets new parameter draw_grob argument, allows user defer drawing tweak gTree object directly.
